name: Helmeted Friarbird
description: It is overall brown, whitish below. It has a silvery crown, red iris, and a low hump at the base of its beak.
food_note: Nectar, various fruits and seeds, invertebrates
reproduction: Females lay 2–4 eggs; further details unknown
attractions: It migrates to follow blooming plants that provide ample nectar. Though nectar is its primary food, it catches insects mid-air with its long tongue. Sometimes called the helmeted hornbill. It has a harsh voice.
breeding: We kept friarbirds from 1997 to 2002, when the August flood interrupted breeding. It resumed in 2010 with a pair from a private breeder. In 2013, another pair arrived from Walsrode Zoo, originally from the wild. They spend winter in the zoo’s back area, away from visitor spaces.
